questions.text: Salter Harris Type 1 injury passes through which zone?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hypertrophic zone 

 

SALTER HARRIS CLASSIFICATION 

  • The arrangement of cells of the physis is in layers or zones. 
  • These layers include the reserve, proliferative and hypertrophic zones. 
  • The reserve zone serves as the storage area for lipids, proteoglycans, and glycogen for growth and matrix production later. 
  • The proliferative zone has the highest rate of extracellular matrix production and accounts for the most abundant longitudinal growth. 
  • The hypertrophic zone has three phases: 
    • Maturation allows for preparation for calcification
    • Degenerative further prepare the matrix
    • Provisional calcification zone is where chondrocyte death occurs, allowing for calcium release. 
  • Physeal fractures most commonly occur in the zone of provisional calcification, as it is the weakest in response to shearing stress. 
  • The physis is weaker than ligaments or periosteum in children, causing injury to the growth plate before other structures. 
  • Zones of physis:

 

 

 

  • Salter and Harris described two major types of epiphyseal plates: the pressure epiphysis and the traction epiphysis. 
  • Pressure epiphyses provide longitudinal growth, at the end of long bones, are intra-articular, and bear weight. 
  • Traction epiphyses provide appositional growth, at the origin or insertion of muscles, are extra-articular, and do not bear weight. 
  • Their classification focuses on injuries at pressure epiphyses. 
  • They recognized that physeal fractures consistently occur through the same histologic plane called the zone of provisional calcification. 
  • This zone, located in the zone of hypertrophy, represents a transitional point between calcified and non-calcified extracellular matrix proteins, making it weaker than its surrounding osseous-ligamentous structures, and therefore more susceptible to injury.

 

 

  • In type I injury, there is slip of epiphysis with damage to the hypertrophic zone of the physis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Resting zone: It is affected in storage disorders like Gaucher’s disease. 

 

Option B. Proliferative zone: It is affected in growth hormone defects like Larsen’s syndrome. 

 

Option D. Zone of provisional calcification: It is affected in mineralization defects like rickets. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Hypertrophic zone of the physis has a high bone turnover. 
  • It is the area where all Salter-Harris injuries occur. 
  • Thus, the Type I injuries occurs in the hypertrophic zone of the physis.

questions.text: Which of the following primary second messengers is involved in the contraction of ciliary muscles while focusing on near objects?(INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) IP3

 

IP3 is the primary second messenger involved in the contraction of ciliary muscles to focus on a near object.

 

The contraction of ciliary muscles of the eye, mediated via M3 receptors, while relaxation is mediated via the B2 receptor.

 

Mg receptors act via the formation of inositol 1,4,5-trisphosphate (IP3) and diacylglycerol (DAG), leading to an increase in intracellular Ca+ and activation of protein kinase C, respectively. The increase in intracellular Ca+ leads to contraction of the ciliary smooth muscle of the eye.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. cAMP: This is incorrect because cAMP is not the primary second messenger involved in the contraction of ciliary muscles for near vision focus. cAMP typically mediates relaxation processes.

 

Option B. cGMP: This is incorrect. cGMP is not involved in the contraction of ciliary muscles for focusing on near objects.

 

Option C. Na+ inflow through a channel: This is incorrect. Na+ inflow is not the primary mechanism for the contraction of ciliary muscles in this context.

 

Educational Objective:

 

IP3 is the primary second messenger involved in the contraction of ciliary muscles necessary for focusing on near objects, mediated by M3 receptors.

questions.text: A middle-aged woman with BMI 32, was on atypical antipsychotic drugs. She presented with a complaint of weight gain. Which of the following drugs is least commonly associated with weight gain? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ziprasidone

 

Atypical antipsychotics are known to vary in their propensity to cause weight gain. Among the options given, ziprasidone is least commonly associated with weight gain.

 

Clozapine and olanzapine are the antipsychotics most commonly associated with significant weight gain, whereas ziprasidone and aripiprazole are associated with minimal to no weight gain.

 

Thus, in the case of a patient concerned about weight gain, ziprasidone would be the preferable choice.

 

 Other Options:

 

Option A. Risperidone: This drug is known to cause moderate weight gain in patients.

 

Option B. Quetiapine: This drug is also associated with weight gain, although not as much as clozapine or olanzapine.

 

Option D. Chlorpromazine: This is a typical antipsychotic and is known to cause significant weight gain.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Among antipsychotic medications, ziprasidone is least commonly associated with weight gain, making it a better option for patients concerned about this side effect.

questions.text: Which of the following effects of puberty are not mediated by estrogen? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Hair growth

 

  • Hair growth (Pubarche): The development of axillary and pubic hair is not mediated by estrogen. It occurs due to testosterone in both sexes.
  • Estrogen effects: Estrogen plays a crucial role in various aspects of puberty, including:
    • Breast development (thelarche)
    • Development of internal genitalia
    • Menarche
    • Regulation of growth spurt
    • Epiphyseal closure
    • Cervical mucus plug formation

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Cervical mucus secretion: Estrogen is responsible for the secretion of cervical mucus.

 

Option C. Vaginal cornification: Estrogen promotes the cornification (maturation) of the vaginal epithelium.

 

Option D. Menstruation: Estrogen is critical in regulating the menstrual cycle and the onset of menarche.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hair growth during puberty is mediated by testosterone, not estrogen. Estrogen is responsible for breast development, internal genitalia development, menarche, growth spurt regulation, epiphyseal closure, and cervical mucus secretion.

 

Ref: Page no 531, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology, 6th edition

questions.text: A woman presents with numbness of her fingertips. On examination, her face is tightened. The antinuclear antibody (ANA) is found to be positive and immunofluorescence shows the nucleolar pattern. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Systemic sclerosis

 

Systemic sclerosis, also known as scleroderma, is characterized by fibrosis and tightening of the skin, particularly on the face and extremities. The presence of numbness in the fingertips is often due to Raynaud's phenomenon, which is common in systemic sclerosis and results from vasospasm and ischemia.

 

The positive ANA test with a nucleolar pattern is highly suggestive of systemic sclerosis. This pattern is seen in more than 95% of patients with scleroderma. Specific antibodies associated with systemic sclerosis include anti-centromere antibodies (often found in limited cutaneous systemic sclerosis) and anti-Scl-70 (anti-topoisomerase I) antibodies (associated with diffuse cutaneous systemic sclerosis).

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Sjogren's syndrome: Sjogren's syndrome primarily affects exocrine glands, leading to dry eyes and mouth. It can also present with positive ANA, but the nucleolar pattern is not typically associated with Sjogren's. The physical findings of skin tightening and fingertip numbness are not characteristic of Sjogren's syndrome.

 

Option C. Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE): SLE is a systemic autoimmune disease that can present with a wide range of symptoms and often includes positive ANA. However, the nucleolar pattern is less common in SLE. The characteristic features of SLE include malar rash, arthritis, and serositis, which are not described in this case.

 

Option D. Rheumatoid arthritis: Rheumatoid arthritis primarily affects the joints, causing chronic inflammatory polyarthritis. While ANA can be positive in rheumatoid arthritis, the nucleolar pattern and symptoms of skin tightening and fingertip numbness are not typical features.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Systemic sclerosis (scleroderma) is associated with positive ANA with a nucleolar pattern, skin tightening, and symptoms like Raynaud's phenomenon. This combination of clinical findings and specific antibody patterns helps in diagnosing systemic sclerosis.

questions.text: Which of the following eye sign is given in the image? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Tache noire

 

The image depicts a condition known as Tache noire, characterized by a triangular brownish discoloration on the sclera. This occurs due to the deposition of bacteria and dust, usually within 3 to 4 hours after death. Tache noire is a postmortem change observed in the eyes of the deceased when the eyelids are partially open, leading to drying of the exposed sclera.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Kevorkian sign: This sign involves the fragmentation of blood in blood vessels into columns due to the loss of blood pressure after death. The characteristic appearance is shown in the image.

 

 

Option C. Corneal changes: These involve alterations in the cornea, such as clouding, that occur after death. However, the given image does not show corneal clouding but rather a specific discoloration indicative of Tache noire.

 

Option D. Vitreous humour changes: These refer to alterations in the vitreous humour of the eye postmortem, such as changes in its consistency or color. The image does not depict such changes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tache noire is a postmortem change characterized by a triangular brownish discoloration on the sclera due to drying and deposition of bacteria and dust, typically occurring within a few hours after death.

questions.text: A petechial rash is associated with all the following, except? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Roseola infantum

 

  • Roseola infantum, also known as exanthem subitum or sixth disease, is a common viral illness caused primarily by human herpesvirus 6 (HHV-6) and sometimes by human herpesvirus 7 (HHV-7). The disease typically affects young children. It is characterized by a high fever lasting for three to five days, which abruptly resolves and is followed by the appearance of a rash. The rash consists of small, rose-pink or red 2 mm to 5 mm papules and macules. A pale halo can occur around the macules and papules in some cases. The rash usually begins on the trunk and can spread to the neck, extremities, and face. It is typically nonpruritic, blanching, and can persist from one to two days.

 

 

Other Options:

 

In contrast, petechial rashes are small, pinpoint, red or purple spots caused by bleeding into the skin and are associated with the following diseases:

 

Option A. Zika Virus: Zika virus infection can cause a mild, dengue-like illness, which includes symptoms like fever, rash, joint pain, and conjunctivitis. The rash can be maculopapular, and in some cases, petechiae can be observed.

 

 

Option C. Kyasanur Forest Disease: This is a tick-borne viral hemorrhagic fever endemic to South India. It is caused by the Kyasanur Forest disease virus (KFDV) and presents with high fever, headache, severe muscle pain, vomiting, gastrointestinal symptoms, and hemorrhagic manifestations, including petechiae.

 

 

Option D. West Nile Fever: This disease is caused by the West Nile virus, which is transmitted by mosquitoes. Symptoms can range from mild to severe, including fever, headache, body aches, skin rash, swollen lymph nodes, and in severe cases, neurological complications. Petechial rashes can occur in some cases.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Roseola infantum is characterized by a rapid onset of a high fever followed by a rash, but it does not typically present with petechial rashes. In contrast, Zika virus, Kyasanur Forest disease, and West Nile fever can cause petechial rashes as part of their clinical manifestations.

choices.text: Children from the area exposed, but unaffected with the disease
Children from the area not exposed and affected with the disease
Children coming to the OPD who do not have the disease
All children with ALL irrespective of exposure status

questions.text: Numerous youngsters from a specific community arrived at a medical facility and were diagnosed with acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL). It was assumed that it is due to the presence of cytotoxic waste in the water of that community. If a case-control investigation were to be conducted to find the potential association between the chemical waste and ALL, what would serve as the control group? [NEET PG 2022]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Children coming to the OPD who do not have the disease

 

Case control study: A study that compares patients who have a disease or outcome of interest (cases) with patients who do not have the disease or outcome (controls), and looks back retrospectively to compare how frequently the exposure to a risk factor is present in each group to determine the relationship between the risk factor and the disease

 

In a case control study, we never try to match the actual risk factor under study

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a case-control study investigating the association between chemical waste exposure and acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL), the control group should consist of children coming to the OPD who do not have the disease (ALL). This ensures a proper baseline for comparison to identify potential risk factors associated with the disease.

choices.text: Weight loss+ Metformin + induction of ovulation with urinary gonadotrophins
Weight loss + folic acid, Try for spontaneous induction, if failed move to induction of ovulation
Metformin + finasteride + Induction of ovulation
Weight loss+ Metformin + Induction of ovulation with clomiphene

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman, experiencing 6 years of infertility, possesses a BMI of 33 and exhibits facial hair. Further investigations have diagnosed her with polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS) and observed tubal spillage from both sides. Given her desire to conceive with her husband, what would be the most suitable management plan for her? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Weight loss + folic acid, try for spontaneous induction, if failed move to induction of ovulation

 

Notably, even a modest weight loss (approximately 5% of body weight) can be beneficial for restoring ovulatory cycles in some obese PCOS patients. Therefore, spontaneous induction is attempted as the first option. Additionally, folic acid is routinely administered as a preventive measure before conception to reduce the risk of neural tube defects.

 

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Weight loss + Metformin + induction of ovulation with urinary gonadotrophins: While weight loss and Metformin are both appropriate treatments for PCOS, initiating ovulation induction with urinary gonadotrophins might be premature. Typically, less invasive methods such as Clomiphene or Letrozole are tried before using gonadotrophins.

 

Option C. Metformin + finasteride + Induction of ovulation: This option includes Metformin, which is beneficial for insulin resistance in PCOS, and finasteride, which is used for hirsutism but not typically for fertility management. Finasteride is not used to induce ovulation. This plan overlooks the initial approach of weight loss and the potential for spontaneous ovulation.

 

Option D. Weight loss + Metformin + Induction of ovulation with clomiphene: This option is partially correct. While weight loss and Metformin are appropriate, the recommendation to immediately use Clomiphene for induction without trying for spontaneous ovulation is not aligned with the step-wise approach in fertility management.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For a woman with PCOS and infertility, the initial management should include weight loss and folic acid supplementation, with attempts at spontaneous ovulation before progressing to more invasive induction methods.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of Kawasaki disease?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Purulent conjunctivitis


Kawasaki disease is a medium vessel vasculitis that typically affects children and involves several characteristic features. The mnemonic "REEMA" helps remember these features:

 

  • R for Rash: Patients with Kawasaki disease often have a polymorphous rash.
  • E for Edema: Edema of the hands and feet is common in Kawasaki disease.
  • E for Eyes: Patients have non-purulent conjunctivitis, which is a hallmark of the disease.
  • M for Mucosal involvement: Mucosal changes include a strawberry tongue and cracked lips.
  • A for Adenopathy: Cervical lymphadenopathy is a typical feature.
  • Patients also exhibit prolonged fever lasting more than five days.
  • Thrombocytosis (increased platelet count) is another feature of Kawasaki disease during the subacute phase.

 

Purulent conjunctivitis, which involves a discharge of pus, is not a feature of Kawasaki disease. Instead, patients typically have non-purulent conjunctivitis.

 

Educational Objective:


Non-purulent conjunctivitis is a feature of Kawasaki disease, whereas purulent conjunctivitis is not.

questions.text: A child presented with hydrocephalus, intracranial calcification, and bilateral chorioretinitis. What can be the most probable diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Congenital Toxoplasmosis
Congenital toxoplasmosis is classically associated with the triad of hydrocephalus, intracranial calcifications, and chorioretinitis. This triad is often remembered as "C3" where C represents chorioretinitis, calcifications (intracranial), and hydrocephalus (cephalus).

Toxoplasma gondii infection in utero can cause these characteristic findings, and they are critical for the diagnosis. These symptoms result from the parasite's effect on the brain and eyes, leading to fluid accumulation (hydrocephalus), calcified lesions in the brain, and inflammation of the choroid and retina.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Congenital Syphilis:  The classical triad of congenital syphilis is represented by "INH" - Interstitial Keratitis, Neurosensory Deafness, and Hutchinson's teeth.

 

 

Option C. Congenital Rubella: The triad associated with congenital rubella includes cataracts, heart disease (often patent ductus arteriosus or other cardiac defects), and neurosensory deafness, summarized as "CHD" (Cataract, Heart Disease, Deafness). It does not involve hydrocephalus, intracranial calcifications, or chorioretinitis.

 

 

Option D. Neisseria gonorrhea: Neisseria gonorrhea is a bacterial infection that typically does not present with a triad of symptoms and is unrelated to congenital infections leading to hydrocephalus, intracranial calcification, or chorioretinitis.

 

Educational Objective:


The classical triad of congenital toxoplasmosis includes hydrocephalus, intracranial calcifications, and chorioretinitis, which are key findings for diagnosis.

questions.text: A 55-year-old female patient presents to the hospital with complaints of abdominal pain and discomfort for the past few months. The patient also reported experiencing weight loss and loss of appetite. On evaluation, a mass is palpable in the upper abdomen, and an endoscopy shows an ulcerated lesion in the stomach. A biopsy of the lesion is taken and sent for immunohistochemistry. The biopsy sample is found to be positive for CD117 and negative for LCA, cytokeratin, and S100. Based on these findings. What is the most likely diagnosis? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) GIST

 

The clinical presentation and the biopsy results suggest the possibility of gastrointestinal stromal tumors (GIST). GIST is the most common mesenchymal tumor of the abdomen, and it typically arises from the interstitial cells of Cajal or the pacemaker cells of the gastrointestinal muscularis propria. GISTs are often associated with symptoms of mass effect, such as abdominal pain and discomfort, and can lead to weight loss and loss of appetite. The diagnosis of GIST is confirmed by immunohistochemistry, which typically shows positivity for KIT (CD117) detectable in Cajal cells. Other immunohistochemical markers such as LCA, cytokeratin, and S100 are negative. Treatment options for GIST may include surgery, radiation therapy, or targeted therapy with tyrosine kinase inhibitors.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Adenocarcinoma: Adenocarcinoma is a common type of cancer that can occur in various organs, including the stomach. However, the immunohistochemistry findings mentioned in the question (positive for CD117 and negative for LCA, cytokeratin, and S100) are not characteristic of adenocarcinoma.

 

Option C. Hodgkin’s lymphoma: Hodgkin's lymphoma is a type of lymphoma that typically presents with enlarged lymph nodes and is characterized by the presence of Reed-Sternberg cells. The immunohistochemistry findings mentioned in the question are not consistent with Hodgkin's lymphoma.

 

Option D. Squamous cell carcinoma: Squamous cell carcinoma is commonly associated with the epithelial lining of organs, and its diagnosis would typically involve positive staining for cytokeratin. The immunohistochemistry findings mentioned in the question (negative for cytokeratin) do not support the diagnosis of squamous cell carcinoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

GISTs are mesenchymal tumors that typically occur in the gastrointestinal tract. They often express CD117 (c-kit), a marker commonly associated with GIST. The negative staining for LCA (Leukocyte Common Antigen), cytokeratin, and S100 helps rule out other possibilities and supports the diagnosis of GIST.

questions.text: A child presents with left to right shunt and high output cardiac failure. The following is his MRI. What is the diagnosis?  (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Vein of Galen malformation

 

The MRI shown is suggestive of Vein of Galen Malformation (VOGM).

 

VOGM:

 

 

  • C/F: Newborn with high output cardiac failure with intracranial bruit
  • Type of A-V fistula
  • Doppler - Large midline vessel seen
  • MRI – Large flow void.
  • CT angiography – Giant vein of galen draining into straight sinus.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Dandy-walker malformation: This is a developmental malformation involving the cerebellum and the fluid spaces around it, characterized by an enlarged posterior cranial fossa. It is not associated with the imaging features seen in the provided MRI, which do not show the typical cerebellar and fourth ventricle abnormalities.

 

 

Option C. Pneumocephalus: This condition involves the presence of air within the cranial cavity, typically seen as areas of radiolucency (dark areas) on imaging, which are not present in the provided MRI.

 

Option D. Venous sinus thrombosis: This condition involves a clot within the dural venous sinuses, which would show different imaging characteristics, such as sinus obstruction or evidence of venous congestion, not observed here.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vein of Galen malformation is a critical diagnosis to consider in infants presenting with signs of high-output cardiac failure, and it can be identified with specific imaging findings such as large flow voids on MRI indicative of abnormal vascular connections.

questions.text: In a seat belt injury, which of the following organs is most commonly affected? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Hollow viscus 

 

Hollow viscus organs such as the small intestine and colon are more commonly affected in seat belt injuries due to their position and vulnerability to compression forces applied by the seat belt.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Liver and spleen: While the liver and spleen can be injured in seat belt injuries, they are not the most commonly affected organs.

 

Option B. Duodenum: The duodenum, being relatively protected by its retroperitoneal location, is less commonly affected in seat belt injuries compared to other abdominal organs.

 

Option C. Pancreas: The pancreas, located deep in the abdomen, can be injured in seat belt injuries, but it is not as commonly affected as other organs.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

In seat belt injuries, hollow viscus organs, particularly the small intestine and colon, are most commonly affected due to their susceptibility to compression forces, emphasizing the importance of thorough evaluation for intra-abdominal injuries.

questions.text: A patient being treated for hypertriglyceridemia developed flushing, gout, hyperglycemia, and raised liver enzymes. Which drug is the most likely cause? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Nicotinamide

 

Nicotinamide, also known as niacin, is a lipid-lowering agent commonly used in the treatment of hypertriglyceridemia. However, it is associated with several side effects that can limit its use. The most common and characteristic side effect of niacin is flushing, which is caused by the release of prostaglandins. This flushing can be intense and uncomfortable for patients, often leading to discontinuation of the drug.

 

In addition to flushing, niacin can cause hyperuricemia, which may precipitate gout, and it can also lead to hyperglycemia and insulin resistance. Furthermore, niacin is hepatotoxic, which can manifest as elevated liver enzymes.

 

While statins can also cause hyperglycemia and hepatotoxicity, they do not cause the flushing or gout that are characteristic of niacin use. Statins are more commonly associated with myopathy, which is not a feature in this scenario.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Atorvastatin: While atorvastatin, a statin, can cause hyperglycemia and raised liver enzymes, it is not typically associated with flushing or gout. Myopathy is the more significant side effect with statins.

 

Option B. Fenofibrate: Fenofibrate, used to treat hypertriglyceridemia, may cause elevated liver enzymes and, rarely, hyperuricemia, but it is not associated with flushing or significant hyperglycemia.

 

Option D. Ezetimibe: Ezetimibe is a cholesterol absorption inhibitor that is generally well tolerated and is not associated with the side effects of flushing, gout, or hyperglycemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Nicotinamide (niacin) is associated with flushing, gout, hyperglycemia, and raised liver enzymes, making it the likely cause of these symptoms in a patient being treated for hypertriglyceridemia

questions.text:
A 30-year-old man presented in OPD with complaints of fever, night sweats, and weight loss for 2 months. On examination, lymphadenopathy was present. They were non-tender, rubbery in consistency, located in the supraclavicular and inguinal regions on both sides. Peripheral smear showed the presence of bi-nucleated cells. Which markers can be identified in this condition? (INICET NOV 2022)

 

  1. CD15
  2. CD30
  3. CD19
  4. CD3
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1 and 2

 

Clinical history and the histopathological examination showing bi-nucleated cells, called Reed Sternberg cells points to a diagnosis of Hodgkins lymphoma. RS cells are CD 15+ and CD30+.

 

Reed-Sternberg cells marker –

 

  • CDI5
  • CD30 (most sensitive)
  • PAX-5 (most SPECIFIC)

 

 

Reed Sternberg Cells are non-specific since it is seen in conditions like:

 

  • Hodgkin’s Lymphoma
  • Non- Hodgkin’s Lymphoma
  • Infection Mononucleosis
  • Sarcoma.

 

Other Options:

 

CD19 (3) and CD3 (4): These markers are associated with B and T cells, respectively. CD19 is a B-cell marker, and CD3 is a T-cell marker. They are not typically associated with Reed-Sternberg cells in Hodgkin's lymphoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In Hodgkin's lymphoma, Reed-Sternberg cells characteristically express CD15 and CD30, making these markers essential for diagnosis.

questions.text: A 35-year-old HIV positive patient presents with mucosal lesions in the mouth as shown in the image below. On microscopy, budding yeasts and pseudohyphae are seen. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Oral candidiasis

 

The most likely diagnosis of the given clinical scenario is oral candidiasis.

 

  • Oral candidiasis or thrush is a patchy, pseudomembranous lesion that develops over the tongue, lips, gum or palate. It is composed of epithelial cells, yeasts, and pseudohyphae. The causative agent is usually Candida albicans.
  • The commonly implemented methods for identifying Candida are 10% potassium hydroxide stain and culture with sabouraud dextrose agar. Differentiation of specific species is possible with special culture mediums like CHROMagar Candida. 
  • ELISA and PCR tests are used in cases of invasive candidiasis and to differentiate Candida dubliniensis from Candida albicans.
  • It occurs in almost all individuals with AIDS. Other risk factors include hyperglycemia, cellular immunodeficiency, corticosteroids or antibiotics.
  • It is treated with topical nystatin or oral ketoconazole or fluconazole.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hairy leukoplakia is a wart-like growth on the tongue, caused by Epstein Barr virus. It is commonly seen as a white lesion on the lateral side of the tongue.

 

Option C. Lichen planus is a pruritic disease characterized by papules commonly seen over the flexor surfaces and trunk. Oral and vulvovaginal lesions may also occur. Oral lesions appear as lacy, white, and raised lesions.

 

Option D. Diphtheria is characterized by the presence of a grey pseudo membrane covering the tonsils and pharynx. It is caused by Corynebacterium diphtheriae.

 

Educational Objective

 

Oral candidiasis is a common opportunistic infection in HIV-positive individuals, characterized by white, patchy lesions in the oral cavity and the presence of Candida species on microscopic examination. Recognizing this condition and distinguishing it from other oral lesions based on clinical presentation and risk factors is crucial for appropriate management, which may include antifungal therapies like nystatin, ketoconazole, or fluconazole.

choices.text: 3 Lac IU

questions.text: Under the guidelines used in India, the dose of Vitamin A for 1-3 years old is:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 2 Lac IU

 

Explanation:

 

According to the immunization schedule and the older Vitamin A prophylaxis program in India, the recommended dose for children up to 1 year of age is 1 lakh international units (IU). For infants below 6 months of age, a dose of 50,000 IU is administered.

Once a child crosses the age of 1 year, the dose increases to 2 lakh IU. This dosage is applicable for toddlers, adolescents, and adults, and is used for both prophylaxis and treatment of Vitamin A deficiency.

 

Other options:

 

  • Option A. 50,000 IU: This dose is recommended for infants below 6 months of age.

 

  • Option B. 1 Lac IU: This dose is given to children up to 1 year of age.

 

  • Option D. 3 Lac IU: Not recommended under the guidelines of Vitamin A prophylaxis program.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For children aged 1-3 years, the recommended dose of Vitamin A under Indian guidelines is 2 lakh international units (IU).

questions.text: Following delivery at a PHC, a patient was referred with the following image. On examination, there is a tear extending to the rectum. Identify the type of tear. (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 4th degree


Perineal tears are classified based on the extent of tissue damage during childbirth:

 

  1. 1st degree: Involves only the vaginal mucosa or skin of the perineum without involving deeper tissues.
  2. 2nd degree: Extends deeper, involving the perineal muscles but does not reach the anal sphincters; similar to an episiotomy.
  3. 3rd degree: Involves the anal sphincter complex with further sub-classifications:
    • 3a: Less than 50% of the external anal sphincter is torn.
    • 3b: More than 50% of the external anal sphincter is torn.
    • 3c: Both the external and internal anal sphincters are involved.
  4. 4th degree: Extends through the rectal mucosa, completely disrupting the sphincters and the rectal lining.

 

Since the tear extends to the rectum, this is classified as a 4th degree tear, the most severe type, involving the entire perineum, anal sphincters, and rectal mucosa.

 

Educational Objective:


A 4th degree tear involves disruption of the anal sphincters and rectal mucosa, making it the most severe form of perineal tear during childbirth.

questions.text: Identify the condition given in the image, which developed after 3 days of catheterization. (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Fournier gangrene 

 

This is a serious bacterial infection characterized by necrotizing fasciitis affecting the perineal, genital, or perianal regions. It often presents with rapid onset, pain, swelling, and crepitus due to gas formation, and is associated with high morbidity and mortality rates. The infection can spread quickly, and early surgical intervention is critical.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Gas gangrene: Also known as clostridial myonecrosis, gas gangrene is caused by infection with Clostridium species and is characterized by sudden, severe pain, swelling, and production of gas, which can be palpable as crepitus

 

Option C. Wet gangrene: This form of gangrene arises when the blood flow to an area is lost, and a bacterial infection develops. It typically affects extremities and is associated with swelling, blistering, and a wet appearance due to pus.

 

Option D. Scrotal hematoma: This is a collection of blood within the scrotal sac but does not involve an infection. It may occur after trauma or surgery. While it can cause swelling and discoloration, it does not present with the same level of systemic illness seen in gangrenous conditions.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Fournier gangrene is a urological emergency that involves necrotizing fasciitis of the external genitalia and requires prompt surgical debridement along with broad-spectrum antibiotics.

questions.text: A farmer presents with pain and discharge in his left eye. He says that he sustained an injury caused by a leaf a few days back. What is the finding seen in the image? (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Hypopyon  

 

The finding seen in the image is hypopyon.

 

  • Hypopyon is an accumulation of inflammatory cells in the anterior chamber of the eye, typically seen in the lower part of the chamber as a whitish exudate.
  • In fungal corneal ulcers, the hypopyon may not be sterile as the fungus can penetrate into the anterior chamber without causing a perforation.
  • Hypopyon associated with anterior uveitis is immobile because of the high fibrin content in the exudate.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: Hyphema is a hemorrhage in the anterior chamber. It commonly occurs after a blunt ocular injury. The bleeding is from the iris root or ciliary body face. The blood settles inferiorly forming a fluid level.

 

 

Option B: Aqueous flare refers to the haziness of the normally clear fluid in the anterior chamber. It reflects the presence of protein due to the breakdown of the blood-aqueous barrier. The presence of flare indicates active inflammation.

 

Option C: Arlt line is the scarring on the conjunctiva in the area of sulcus subtarsalis. It can be a single line, irregularly shaped, or star-shaped. Common causes are trachoma, healed traumatic wounds, or surgical scars.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hypopyon is points to severe intraocular inflammation needing prompt treatment to preserve eye function and prevent potential complications. The presence of hypopyon after an injury with organic material highly suggests a fungal etiology, requiring specific antifungal treatment alongside broad-spectrum antibacterial coverage.

questions.text: In the given image, the tendon marked by the arrow is: (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Flexor carpi radialis

 

Explanation:

 

The image shows the anterior compartment of the forearm, focusing on the tendons near the wrist. The arrow is pointing to a tendon that runs from the forearm to the wrist and to the palm. This tendon belongs to the flexor carpi radialis muscle. The flexor carpi radialis is one of the superficial flexor muscles of the forearm. It plays a crucial role in flexion and abduction of the wrist.

 

Flexor Carpi Radialis: The flexor carpi radialis tendon is located just lateral to the palmaris longus tendon. It is prominent and easily palpable in many individuals.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Flexor carpi ulnaris: This is incorrect. The flexor carpi ulnaris tendon is located medial to the palmaris longus tendon and runs towards the pisiform bone.

 

Option C. Flexor digitorum superficialis: This is incorrect. The flexor digitorum superficialis tendons are deeper and run to the fingers, responsible for flexion of the middle phalanges.

 

Option D. Palmaris longus: This is incorrect. The palmaris longus tendon runs from the forearm to the palm and is more centrally located in the wrist. It is a thin tendon that is absent in about 14% of the population.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The flexor carpi radialis is a superficial flexor muscle of the forearm with a prominent tendon that runs from the forearm to the base of the second and third metacarpals, playing a key role in wrist flexion and abduction.

questions.text: Decreased transferrin saturation is seen in: (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Iron deficiency anemia

  

Transferrin saturation is a measure of the percentage of transferrin (iron-transporting protein) that is saturated with iron. In iron deficiency anemia, there is a lack of sufficient iron to saturate transferrin, leading to a decreased transferrin saturation. This occurs because the body has insufficient iron for proper incorporation into hemoglobin and other iron-containing proteins.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hemochromatosis: In hemochromatosis, there is an excessive absorption and accumulation of iron in the body. This condition leads to increased transferrin saturation, as the body has an excess of iron.

 

Option C. Macrocytic anemia: Macrocytic anemia refers to anemia with larger-than-normal red blood cells. It is commonly associated with deficiencies in vitamin B12 or folic acid. Transferrin saturation is not typically a characteristic feature of macrocytic anemia.

 

Option D. Hemosiderosis: Hemosiderosis refers to the deposition of excess iron in tissues. Like hemochromatosis, it is associated with increased transferrin saturation due to iron overload.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The educational objective here is to understand the concept of transferrin saturation and how it relates to various conditions related to iron metabolism. Decreased transferrin saturation is typically seen in conditions of iron deficiency, such as iron deficiency anemia, where there is insufficient iron to fully saturate transferrin.

questions.text: At the 5th postnatal day, a woman presents with sadness, irritability, restlessness, and reduced sleep. What is the diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Postpartum blues

 

Explanation:

 

Postpartum blues, also known as "baby blues," typically occur within the first few days after delivery and can last up to two weeks. It is characterized by mood swings, sadness, irritability, restlessness, and difficulty sleeping. These symptoms are usually mild and self-limiting, resolving on their own with support and reassurance.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Postpartum depression: This condition occurs after the first two weeks post-delivery and can persist for months. It includes more severe symptoms such as persistent sadness, lack of interest in the baby, feelings of hopelessness, and possibly suicidal thoughts.

 

Option C. Postpartum anxiety: This condition involves excessive worry, anxiety, and often includes physical symptoms like palpitations or hyperventilation. It can occur at any time during the postpartum period.

 

Option D. Postpartum psychosis: This is a rare but severe condition that usually occurs within the first few weeks after delivery. It involves symptoms such as hallucinations, delusions, severe agitation, and risk of harm to the mother or baby.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Postpartum blues are common in the first few days after delivery and are characterized by sadness, irritability, restlessness, and reduced sleep. The condition is generally mild and self-limiting, resolving with support and care.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male came with a history of progressive dysphagia, initially to solid foods and now to liquids too. He has also experienced significant weight loss over the past few months. Which of the following is the investigation of choice for diagnosing the underlying cause of his symptoms? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Upper GI Endoscopy 

 

The patient's symptoms of progressive dysphagia first to solids and then to liquids, along with significant weight loss, are concerning for an esophageal pathology, possibly a malignancy. 

 

This is the investigation of choice for evaluating dysphagia. It allows direct visualization of the esophageal lumen, can detect strictures, masses, or other abnormalities, and offers the possibility of biopsy, which is essential for diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Endoscopic ultrasound: This can provide detailed images of the esophageal wall and adjacent structures and is useful for staging esophageal cancer. It is generally not the first test ordered when investigating dysphagia.

 

Option C. Contrast-enhanced computed tomography (CECT): While CECT can provide information about the extent of a disease and help in staging cancer, it is not the first-line investigation for dysphagia and cannot provide a definitive diagnosis without endoscopic visualization and biopsy.

 

Option D. Barium swallow: A barium swallow X-ray study can show structural changes in the esophagus, such as narrowing or obstruction, and is useful in diagnosing conditions like achalasia or strictures. However, it is less definitive than endoscopy for tissue diagnosis.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Upper GI endoscopy is the first-line diagnostic tool for evaluating a patient with progressive dysphagia and significant weight loss, as it allows for direct visualization and biopsy to establish a definitive diagnosis.

questions.text: The cross product ratio can be obtained by: [NEET PG 2019]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) Case control study

 

The cross-product ratio is a measure of association between two categorical variables, and it can be arrived at from a case-control study.

 

In a case-control study, the odds ratio (OR) is often used as a measure of association between the exposure and the outcome. The cross-product ratio is an alternative measure of association that can be derived from the odds ratio.

 

Interpretation

 

OR> 1 → Association Present

OR =1 → No Association

OR< 1 → Inverse/Negative Association → RF is protective(beneficial)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ecological study: This type of study examines the associations between exposure and outcomes at the population or group level, not at the individual level, and does not typically use the cross-product ratio.

 

Option B. Cohort study: This type of study follows a group of exposed and non-exposed individuals over time to observe the incidence of outcomes. It uses relative risk rather than the cross-product ratio.

 

Option C. Cross-sectional study: This study observes a population at a single point in time, assessing both exposure and outcome simultaneously. It can measure prevalence but not the cross-product ratio specifically.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The cross-product ratio, or odds ratio, is a measure of association commonly derived from case-control studies to determine the relationship between exposure and outcome.

questions.text: A 30-year-old pregnant woman with a history of chronic sun exposure presented with bilateral brownish pigmentation over the face as shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Melasma

 

Melasma is characterized by bilateral, symmetrical brownish pigmentation, primarily on the face, commonly seen in pregnant women or individuals with chronic sun exposure. In this case, the patient's history of pregnancy and chronic sun exposure, along with the image showing patchy pigmentation, strongly suggests melasma. Melasma in pregnant women is often referred to as chloasma or the "mask of pregnancy." It is associated with hormonal changes and UV exposure. Additionally, melasma is often linked to thyroid disorders.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Melanoma: Melanoma is typically characterized by the ABCDE features: Asymmetry, Border irregularity, Color variation, Diameter greater than 6mm, and Evolution of the lesion.

 

 

Option C. Suntan: A suntan results in diffuse pigmentation over sun-exposed areas, usually with an initial red phase. The pigmentation in a suntan is not patchy as seen in the image provided but rather more uniform. Therefore, suntan is not the correct diagnosis.

 

 

Option D. Nevus of OTA: This condition presents with unilateral blue or grey pigmentation, often involving the sclera and skin on the face. The absence of these characteristic features and the presence of bilateral brown pigmentation make Nevus of OTA an incorrect choice.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Melasma, especially in pregnant women, presents as bilateral, symmetrical brownish patches on the face, often linked to sun exposure and hormonal changes.

choices.text: Sporothrix schenckii
Staphylococcus aureus
Nocardia asteroides

questions.text: A young man presents with skin lesions as shown in the image below. All of the following organisms can spread through dermal and subcutaneous lymphatics, except? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Staphylococcus aureus

 

Although Staphylococcus aureus can cause various skin infections, including cellulitis, abscesses, and impetigo, it does not typically spread through dermal and subcutaneous lymphatics in the characteristic pattern of lymphocutaneous spread. Staphylococcus aureus usually causes localized infections.

 

Other Options

 

Organisms that can spread through dermal and subcutaneous lymphatics:

 

Option A. Sporothrix schenckii: Causes sporotrichosis, also known as "rose gardener's disease," which presents with nodular lymphangitis, characterized by lesions following the lymphatic drainage.

 

Option C. Nocardia asteroides: Nocardiosis can present with cutaneous and subcutaneous lesions that spread along lymphatics, particularly in immunocompromised individuals.

 

Option D. Mycobacterium marinum: Causes swimming pool granuloma or fish tank granuloma, presenting with skin lesions that spread along lymphatic channels.

 

Educational Objective

 

While Sporothrix schenckii, Nocardia asteroides, and Mycobacterium marinum are known to spread through dermal and subcutaneous lymphatics, causing lymphocutaneous lesions, Staphylococcus aureus typically causes localized skin infections and does not exhibit this pattern of spread.

questions.text: Vitamin A deficiency is characteristic of: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Bitot spots

 

Bitot spots are a characteristic sign of vitamin A deficiency. They appear as dry, foamy, triangular patches on the conjunctiva, typically on the temporal side of the cornea. These spots are part of a condition called xerophthalmia, which is dryness of the eye due to vitamin A deficiency. Bitot spots represent a more advanced stage of xerophthalmia, classified as stage X1B in the WHO classification of vitamin A deficiency.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Stocker's line: This is an iron deposition line seen in front of a pterygium. It is not related to vitamin A deficiency.

 

 

Option B. Pinguecula: This is a yellowish, raised lesion on the conjunctiva near the corneal limbus. It's caused by elastotic degeneration due to prolonged UV exposure, not vitamin A deficiency.

 

 

Option C. Pterygium: This is a wing-shaped growth of conjunctiva extending onto the cornea. Like pinguecula, it's associated with UV exposure and not vitamin A deficiency.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bitot spots are a characteristic sign of vitamin A deficiency, appearing as dry, foamy patches on the conjunctiva and representing stage X1B of xerophthalmia.

questions.text: Which of the following forms the lateral boundary of the femoral triangle? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Medial margin of sartorius

 

Explanation:

 

The femoral triangle is a triangular muscular depression located in the upper part of the thigh. Its boundaries are formed by the inguinal ligament (base), the medial margin of the sartorius muscle (lateral boundary), and the medial border of the adductor longus muscle (medial boundary). The apex of the triangle is formed by the intersection of the sartorius and adductor longus muscles.

 

The sartorius muscle, the longest muscle in the body, originates from the anterior superior iliac spine (ASIS) and forms the lateral boundary of the femoral triangle with its medial margin. The adductor longus muscle, originating from the pubic tubercle area, forms the medial boundary of the triangle.

 

The floor of the femoral triangle is formed by the adductor longus, pectineus, psoas major tendon, and iliacus muscle (Mnemonic "APPI"). The roof of the triangle is formed by the skin, superficial fascia, and deep fascia.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lateral margin of adductor longus: Incorrect. The adductor longus muscle forms the medial boundary of the femoral triangle, not the lateral boundary.

 

Option B. Medial margin of adductor longus: Incorrect. The medial margin of the adductor longus muscle forms the medial boundary of the femoral triangle, not the lateral boundary.

 

Option C. Lateral margin of sartorius: Incorrect. The sartorius muscle forms the lateral boundary of the femoral triangle, but it is the medial margin of the sartorius that specifically forms this boundary.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The medial margin of the sartorius muscle forms the lateral boundary of the femoral triangle, while the medial border of the adductor longus muscle forms the medial boundary.

choices.text: Urgent referral to the tertiary care centre immediately
Administer IV antibiotics and ask the patient to be brought after 24 hours

questions.text: A 2-year-old toddler with a weight of 11 kg was brought to the pediatric outpatient department. The child exhibited a respiratory rate of 38 breaths per minute and upon examination, noticeable chest indrawing was detected. What is the next step of management? [NEET PG 2020]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Oral amoxicillin for five days

 

According to the latest revised guidelines by WHO, the management of childhood pneumonia has been updated based on new evidence. In the given scenario, a 2-year-old child presents with a respiratory rate of 38 breaths per minute and chest indrawing, which fits the criteria for pneumonia but without general danger signs. According to the revised classification, the appropriate management for this case is oral amoxicillin for five days and home care advice.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Urgent referral to the tertiary care centre immediately: This is recommended for children showing general danger signs or very severe disease, not for pneumonia with chest indrawing without other danger signs.

 

Option C. Administer IV antibiotics and ask the patient to be brought after 24 hours: This would be applicable for severe cases requiring inpatient care, not for managing a case of pneumonia without general danger signs at an outpatient department.

 

Option D. Start antipyretics urgently: While antipyretics may be used to manage fever, they do not address the underlying pneumonia and are not the primary management step in this scenario.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text:
Which of the following tests can be used if otoacoustic emissions is absent for screening?(INICET NOV 2022)

 

  1. Pure tone audiometry
  2. Tympanometry
  3. Free field audiometry
  4. Speech audiometry
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 2 and 4

 

When otoacoustic emissions (OAE) are absent, it indicates a potential cochlear pathology, specifically affecting the outer hair cells. Further testing is required to assess the extent and nature of hearing loss, as well as to rule out any retrocochlear pathology.

 

2. Tympanometry: This test assesses the condition of the middle ear and tympanic membrane mobility by creating variations in air pressure in the ear canal. It is useful to determine if the absence of OAEs might be related to middle ear issues, such as fluid, which can mask cochlear function.

 

4. Speech Audiometry: This test evaluates the ability to understand speech and also provides information about the clarity of speech perception. It helps to determine the speech recognition threshold and is crucial for diagnosing the degree and type of hearing loss when OAEs are absent.

 

Other Options:

 

1. Pure Tone Audiometry: While this test is crucial for determining the threshold levels of hearing and the degree of hearing loss across different frequencies, it was not specified as one of the correct responses in this context.

 

3. Free Field Audiometry: Generally used for young children or individuals who cannot reliably use headphones, this test measures hearing sensitivity to sounds presented in an open field. However, it requires a controlled sound field, which is not always practical for immediate follow-up when OAEs are absent.

 

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 29

choices.text: Bicarbonate in the intracellular compartment
Calcium in the extracellular compartment

questions.text: Gibbs-Donnan equilibrium is mainly due to? (INICET Nov 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Intracellular proteins

 

Gibbs-Donnan equilibrium is mainly due to intracellular proteins.

 

The Gibbs-Donnan effect describes the unequal distribution of Diffusible charged ions on either side of a semipermeable membrane which occurs in the presence of impermeant charged ions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Phosphate: While phosphate ions are present in both intracellular and extracellular compartments, they are not the primary cause of the Gibbs-Donnan equilibrium. Their concentrations do not significantly contribute to the electrochemical gradient and osmotic balance in the same way as intracellular proteins do.

 

Option B. Bicarbonate in the intracellular compartment: Bicarbonate ions are crucial for maintaining acid-base balance, but they are not the main factor in establishing the Gibbs-Donnan equilibrium. Their movement across membranes is more related to pH regulation rather than creating an electrochemical gradient due to impermeant ions.

 

Option C. Calcium in the extracellular compartment: Calcium ions are essential for various cellular functions, including muscle contraction and neurotransmission, but they do not play a primary role in the Gibbs-Donnan equilibrium. Their concentration differences across membranes are tightly regulated by channels and pumps, rather than by the presence of impermeant ions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

At Gibbs-Donnan equilibrium,

 

  • On each side of the membrane, each solution will be electrically neutral
  • The product of diffusible ions on one side of the membrane will be equal to the product of diffusible ions on the other side of the membrane
  • The electrochemical gradients produced by unequal distribution of charged ions produces a transmembrane potential difference which can be calculated using the Nernst equation
  • The presence of impermeant ions on one side of the membrane creates an osmotic diffusion gradient attracting water into that compartment.

 

Intracellular proteins are negatively charged non-permeable ions, then distribution of other permeable ions is affected in a predictable way (Donnan Effect) so that at equilibrium their concentration ratios are equal.

questions.text: Multiple abscesses with discharging sinuses, demonstrating sulphur granules in pus, are caused by:  (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Actinomyces

 

Multiple abscesses with discharging sinuses, demonstrating sulfur granules in pus, are characteristic of actinomycosis caused by Actinomyces.

 

Actinomycosis is a chronic granulomatous infection characterized by indurated swellings mainly in the connective tissue with suppuration and discharge of sulfur granules. The most common causative agent is Actinomyces israelli

 

Various clinical forms of actinomycosis include cervicofacial, thoracic, abdominal, and pelvic actinomycosis.

 

Among them, actinomycosis most commonly occurs as oral-cervicofacial form presenting as a soft tissue swelling, abscess, or mass lesion involving the angle of the jaw.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Nocardia: Incorrect, although Nocardia can also cause cutaneous infections with abscess and sinus formation, it does not produce sulfur granules.

 

Option C. Salmonella: Incorrect, known primarily for causing gastrointestinal infections rather than chronic skin and soft tissue infections.

 

Option D. Tularemia: Incorrect, although it can cause ulceroglandular disease with skin ulcers and lymphadenopathy, it does not produce sulfur granules.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Actinomycosis, particularly its cervicofacial form, is characterized by the formation of abscesses that discharge pus containing sulfur granules. This hallmark feature helps in diagnosing the disease, which requires prolonged antibiotic therapy due to its chronic and indurative nature.

choices.text: 2,3 and 4
1,2,3 and 4
4 only
1 and 2 only

questions.text:
Ketosis is common in type 1 DM due to: (INICET Nov 2020)

1. Decreased beta-oxidation of fatty acids

2. Increased mobilization of fat from the adipose cell

3. Decreased acetyl Co in TCA cycle

4. Increased beta-hydroxy butyrate synthase
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 2, 3 and 4

 

2, 3 and 4 statements correctly explain the reason behind increased ketogenesis as seen in type1 DM.

 

In Type 1 DM insulin is deficient and GLUT4 (insulin-dependent uptake) mediated glucose uptake is not possible in the heart or skeletal muscles. So, fat is mobilized from adipose tissue for energy.

 

 

The following points explain the reasons behind increased ketogenesis:

 

Statement 2: Increased Mobilization of Fat from the Adipose Cell: In type 1 DM, insulin deficiency leads to increased lipolysis in adipose tissue, resulting in the release of free fatty acids into the bloodstream. These fatty acids are transported to the liver, where they undergo beta-oxidation.

Statement 3: Decreased Acetyl CoA in the TCA Cycle: Insulin deficiency also leads to reduced availability of oxaloacetate in the liver, which is diverted to gluconeogenesis. This decreases the entry of acetyl CoA into the TCA cycle, causing an accumulation of acetyl CoA.

Statement 4: Increased Beta-Hydroxybutyrate Synthase: The increased concentration of acetyl CoA leads to the synthesis of ketone bodies, including beta-hydroxybutyrate. The enzyme beta-hydroxybutyrate dehydrogenase catalyzes the conversion of acetoacetate to beta-hydroxybutyrate.

 

Other Statements:

  • Decreased Beta-Oxidation of Fatty Acids (1): This is incorrect. In type 1 DM, beta-oxidation of fatty acids is actually increased due to the elevated levels of free fatty acids resulting from enhanced lipolysis.

 

Additional Context:

In the absence of insulin, glucose uptake by cells is impaired, leading to increased lipolysis and subsequent beta-oxidation of fatty acids. The resulting acetyl CoA cannot enter the TCA cycle efficiently due to low levels of oxaloacetate, leading to the production of ketone bodies (acetoacetate, beta-hydroxybutyrate, and acetone).

 

Educational Objective

 

Ketosis in type 1 diabetes mellitus is caused by increased mobilization of fat from adipose tissue, decreased entry of acetyl CoA into the TCA cycle, and increased production of ketone bodies, particularly beta-hydroxybutyrate.

questions.text: In a solid organ transplantation, which organ is associated with a higher incidence of rejection? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Lungs

 

Lung transplantation is associated with a higher incidence of rejection compared to other solid organ transplants due to the lungs' constant exposure to environmental antigens and their role in gas exchange, which increases the risk of immune-mediated injury.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Intestine: Intestinal transplantation also carries a high risk of rejection, but it is less common than lung rejection and is often associated with complications such as graft-versus-host disease.

 

Option C. Kidney: Kidney transplantation has a relatively lower incidence of rejection compared to lung and intestinal transplants due to the kidney's immunologically privileged status and the availability of effective immunosuppressive medications.

 

Option D. Heart: While heart transplantation can also lead to rejection, it generally has a lower incidence compared to lung transplantation, possibly due to differences in the immune response and the heart's unique anatomical and physiological characteristics.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Lung transplantation is associated with a higher incidence of rejection compared to other solid organ transplants due to the lungs' constant exposure to environmental antigens, emphasizing the need for vigilant monitoring and immunosuppressive therapy in lung transplant recipients.

questions.text: Which of the following is the correct treatment protocol for pulmonary tuberculosis in children? (Fmge July 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 2HRZE + 4 HRE

 

The correct treatment protocol for pulmonary tuberculosis in children is typically 2 months of HRZE (isoniazid, rifampicin, pyrazinamide, and ethambutol) followed by 4 months of HRE (isoniazid, rifampicin, and ethambutol). This regimen aligns with WHO guidelines for treating pediatric tuberculosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 4HRZE + 2HR: This regimen is not a standard treatment protocol for pulmonary tuberculosis in children.

 

Option C. 2HRZE + 4 HR + corticosteroids: Corticosteroids are not routinely used in the standard treatment of pulmonary tuberculosis in children.

 

Option D. 4 HRZE + 2 HRE: This regimen is not consistent with standard treatment guidelines for pediatric tuberculosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The correct treatment protocol for pulmonary tuberculosis in children involves 2 months of HRZE followed by 4 months of HRE, aligning with WHO guidelines for pediatric TB treatment.

questions.text: Which of the following is a primary skin lesion? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Purpura

 

Purpura is a primary skin lesion. It is a disorder that causes red or purple areas on the skin that do not blanch when pressure is applied. RBC extravasation into the skin is the reason for these red patches.

 

It occurs under the following circumstances:

 

  • Vasculitis
  • Thrombocytopenia
  • Vitamin C deficiency.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: Crust: A secondary lesion that forms when serum, blood, or other exudates dry on the skin surface.

 

Option B: Atrophy: A secondary lesion characterized by a thinning of any part of the skin due to loss of collagen, elastin, or fat.

 

Option D: Induration: A secondary change resulting in the hardening of the skin, often due to an inflammatory response or chronic disease affecting deeper layers like the dermis and subcutaneous tissue.

 

Additional Information

 

Primary lesions of the skin include:

 

  • Papule Plaque Nodule
  • Vesicle Bulla
  • Macule Patch
  • Pustule Abscess
  • Petechiae Purpura Ecchymosis
  • Wheal

 

Primary Lesion:

 

1. Flat Lesions (Neither raised Nor Depressed)

 

 

2. Circumscribed solid raised lesions

 

 

3. Clear fluid filled lesions

 

 

4. Pus filled lesions

 

 

5.  Wheal

 

 

6.  Extravasation of RBC→ Skin/Mucosa

 

 

Secondary lesions of the skin include:

 

  • Lichenification 
  • Atrophy
  • Ulcer
  • Erosion
  • Excoriation
  • Crust
  • Induration
  • Scar 
  • Fissure
  • Scale

 

Educational Objective:

 

Purpura is a primary skin lesion indicative of an underlying vascular or coagulation disorder, differentiating it from secondary skin lesions such as crusts, atrophy, and induration, which result from external factors or the progression of skin diseases is also crucial.

 

 

Reference: Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition Chapter 4 page no 4.10

Question Level – Intermediate

Question Id-7437 Unique Key-Q1311505

questions.text: A 59-year-old patient who underwent cataract surgery, presented with gradual diminution of vision in the operated eye, suggesting secondary cataract. Which laser is used for the management of this patient? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Nd:YAG

 

  • Posterior capsular opacification is also known as “after cataract” or “secondary cataract”.
  • It is a late complication of cataract surgery.
  • There are three morphological types: Elschnig pearls (most common), Sommering ring, and diffuse membranous.
  • Symptoms include a gradual, painless decrease in vision.
  • Treatment involves the use of laser Nd:YAG (1064 nm wavelength). Tough and nonpliable membrane have first to be cut into smaller pieces by Ziegler knife or vitreous scissor.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Femto second laser: Used in LASIK, cataract surgery, corneal transplant, and keratoconus treatment, but not for treating secondary cataract.

 

Option C. EXCIMER: Used for photorefractive keratectomy (PRK), LASIK, phototherapeutic keratectomy (PTK), and corneal cross-linking, but not for secondary cataract.

 

Option D. Argon laser: Used in retinal photocoagulation, trabeculoplasty, and iridotomy, but not for secondary cataract.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Various lasers and their uses in ophthalmological procedures: -

choices.text: Rupture membranes and confirm cord prolapse
Put the cord above the vertex

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman is in labor. The cervix is 3 cm dilated and 70% effaced. A "bag of worms" is felt. What is the next best step? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Emergency LSCS

 

The description "bag of worms" suggests a cord prolapse, a critical situation where the umbilical cord precedes the fetus, risking compression. An emergency lower segment caesarean section (LSCS) is vital to prevent fetal distress or demise.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Rupture membranes and confirm cord prolapse: Rupturing membranes could worsen cord compression.

 

Option C. Put the cord above the vertex: Attempting to reposition the cord is risky and generally not recommended.

 

Option D. Wait for spontaneous delivery: Waiting is not advisable due to the risk of cord compression and fetal hypoxia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of suspected cord prolapse during labor, an emergency LSCS is the recommended course of action to safely deliver the baby and minimize the risk of complications.
